title: Replace the application/http-exchange+cbor format with a simpler format.
body:
This format:
* Doesn't require a streaming CBOR parser parse it from a network stream.
* Doesn't allow request payloads or response trailers, which don't fit into
  the signature model.
* Allows checking the signature before parsing the exchange headers.

This is similar to, but not exactly the same as the format @davidben proposed for #139: it pulls out the `Signature` header into bytestring before the other headers so that the second map can be literally the bytes in the signed string. This isn't extensible if we ever want to add new non-signed values, so I added a format version number into the format's magic number.

[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/no-streaming/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html), [Diff](https://tools.ietf.org/rfcdiff?url1=https://wicg.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt&url2=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/no-streaming/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt)

Fixes #135.

title: "Signed Exchange" Generator implementation
body:
This PR introduces a generator tool which implements the "Signed HTTP Exchange" proposed as in https://wicg.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html

The code is written by @hajimehoshi, @nyaxt, @irori (all Googlers, thus can skip CLA) with adopted code from https://github.com/WICG/webpackage/tree/master/go/webpack.

title: Update the README.
body: A quick update to the README that fixes #115. This doesn't update the explainer, which is still aimed at the pre-layered format.

title: Update to the -23 TLS1.3 draft.
body:
That draft splits the rsa_pss signature algorithm names to depend on the key's OID. I suspect all RSA keys in the wild use the rsaEncryption OID, so banning that (to avoid Bleichenbacher attacks) would be equivalent to banning RSA keys, but if not, maybe we could allow the RSASSA-PSS ones.

@sleevi @davidben

title: Cleanup and introduction improvements
body:
[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/cleanup/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html), [Diff](https://tools.ietf.org/rfcdiff?url1=https://wicg.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt&url2=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/cleanup/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt)

@KenjiBaheux, the introduction here should be usable as a simple explainer. Please check that it's readable and explains enough.

title: Define application/http-exchange+cbor.
body:
[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/envelope-format/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html#application-http-exchange)

This format wraps an HTTP exchange, which allows an HTTP/1 connection to
transfer cross-origin signed exchanges, and which may have other uses.

@kinu @yoavweiss Does this look reasonable?

title: Specifying the Accept-Signature header to ask for signatures.
Sign just the headers and identify a header to guard the payload.
body:
[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/incremental-validity/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html), [Diff](https://tools.ietf.org/rfcdiff?url1=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt&url2=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/incremental-validity/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt) (When TravisCI recovers.)

This limits the length of the signed data, which helps validation
routines use the non-prehashed variant of ed25519, and if the MI header
field is used, it allows clients to incrementally trust the beginning
chunks of the payload as they are received instead of needing to wait
for the whole thing.

title: remove stray period
Use CBOR maps in signed exchanges.
body:
Instead of arrays with alternating keys and values, which side-steps the
disagreement about CBOR canonical map ordering rules, I now specify one
of the ordering rules and use maps where they make sense.

The one place I'm still not using a map is in the top level of the
exchange representation, where the request/response/payload ordering
seems useful and where we might someday want to add, for example, the
request payload between the request and response.

[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/use-maps/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html), [Diff](https://tools.ietf.org/rfcdiff?url1=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt&url2=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/use-maps/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt)

@MikeBishop

title: Start writing the bundling spec.
body:
[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/bundles/draft-yasskin-dispatch-bundled-exchanges.html)

This fills a similar niche as [MHTML](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2557), but
* is random access,
* efficiently encodes 8-bit payloads,
* can represent multiple top-level resources,
* can represent content-negotiated resources,
* and possibly other advantages.

I believe that combined with [signed exchanges](https://wicg.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html), bundles fill all of the [web packaging use cases](https://wicg.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-webpackage-use-cases.html) except for "Third-party security review", which will probably want to insist on a consistent version of contained resources.

title: Fix some comments from Yoav Weiss.
body: @yoavweiss

title: Add EdDSA certificates to the set with defined signature algorithms.
body:
I used the pre-hashed variants for those and switched the raw ed25519
public key to use ed25519ph, with an Open Question for whether that's
the right choice.

Ilari Liusvaara pointed out that draft-ietf-curdle-pkix is nearly published, so it makes sense to include its public key types in this document now. 

@sleevi, is this the right choice?

[Preview](https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/define-ed25519-certs/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html#signature-validity), [Diff](https://tools.ietf.org/rfcdiff?url1=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt&url2=https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/define-ed25519-certs/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.txt)

title: Rewrite (X, section Y) to (Section Y of X).
body: In the hopes of getting deep links. Pointed out in https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/ietf-http-wg/2017OctDec/0399.html. However, https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-origin-frame-04#section-1 does have a deep link to [RFC7540], Section 9.1.2, so I don't think this ordering is the fundamental problem. I can't get any of these syntaxes to result in deep links from https://xml2rfc.tools.ietf.org/, so I'm not sure what the ietf-httpbis drafts are doing to get them. The httpsbis editors' drafts do *not* have deep links: http://httpwg.org/http-extensions/expect-ct.html#response-header-field-syntax @MikeBishop, halp! 😺

title: Remove the worry about not signing the whole cert chain.

Preview at https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/remove-chain-signing-question/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html#signature-validity.

title: Turn the PUSH-replacement use case into a non-goal.
body:
Preview at https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/demote-push-ergonomics/draft-yasskin-webpackage-use-cases.html#push-replacement

@slightlyoff @dglazkov: I included this as a goal because y'all keep talking about it, but the PUSH experts like @yoavweiss and @igrigorik think we should just stop talking about it and rely on the other benefits instead, so here's a PR to demote it.

title: Avoid use of "CDN", which implies a CNAME to many people.
body:
Use "content distributor" instead, in the hope that it only implies
distribution without authority.

How's this, @yoavweiss?

Previews in https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/clarify-cdn/.

title: A rough proposal for signing HTTP exchanges.
body:
There's a preview at https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/design-signatures/draft-yasskin-http-origin-signed-responses.html#proposal

What's clearly broken about this? Is the complexity of allowing either plain responses or encapsulated request headers worth it?

I updated the validity algorithm to handle raw public keys and to return exactly which headers are trustworthy, but I did it quickly, so there could be mistakes there.

title: Add a security consideration to revoke keys exposed by a signing oracle.
body: How's this, @agl, @sleevi?

body: I hope this'll make it a little easier to follow along as things move into formal standards bodies.

Did I miss anything obvious or say anything incorrect?

This also adds an explicit "Implementations are hard to get wrong" requirement.

title: Start an Internet Draft for signed single responses.
An initial use-cases document for the web packaging proposal.
body:
Preview at https://jyasskin.github.io/webpackage/draft-webpackage-use-cases/draft-yasskin-webpackage-use-cases.html

@mnot, you seemed to have some use cases for signing individual request/response/body triples, but I don't remember what they were. Could you list a couple so I can add them to this document?

title: Describe the TAG's draft as out-of-date.
body: I've heard from at least two people who started reading the TAG's document instead of this one because of how prominently we highlight it.

title: Write an internet draft
body:
Fixes #71. I'm going to submit the draft to the IETF before this is reviewed in order to make their July 3 deadline, but I definitely want y'all to point out problems so I can fix them in the next draft.

I've pre-emptively removed the :method header (#70) and changed the `sections` map into an array, and I'll backfill those into the explainer and implementation when I get a bit more time.

title: Update the signed one-origin example.
body: This update was generated using #67, but we can commit it without all that code.

title: Add support for encrypted and missing keys to wpktext2cbor.
body: This depends on #62.

title: Add a simple CBOR parser to make it easier to test the CBOR writer.
Remove unused code from Package.
Define how to pick a signing algorithm based on a certificate's public key.
body: And add some Go code to sign a message into a byte string.

title: Refine the algorithm for hashing a resource.
body: Headers are decompressed before being hashed.

title: Write signed manifests to the CBOR format.
body: This sits on top of #55, #60, #61, #63, #64, #65, and #66. Sorry that it's so long again.

title: Rearrange writing the resource body so it doesn't have to materialize in memory.
body: Using a Writer makes it easier to hash the resource at the same time it's being written to the CBOR serialization.

title: Store URL and status in HTTP2 pseudoheaders.
Improve readability.
body: I'll try to get some experienced Go programmers to review this and suggest other ways to improve readability, as requested in https://github.com/dimich-g/webpackage/pull/53#pullrequestreview-38510830.

title: Parse manifests
body: There's no support yet for serializing the text format including manifest data, or serializing and signing the CBOR format.

title: Add a function to parse the text format from an inline manifest.
body: This lets me write tests without adding a new file for each test.

title: Write a package in two passes, which lets me remove support for "pending" ints.
body:
It also removes the O(#parts^2) slowdown from inserting offsets one at a time, and makes it possible to build packages larger than fit in memory.

@mrdewitt

title: Split the Local Sharing use case into shapshots and signed apps.
body: Is there a more official link to the Chrome MHTML work than http://www.techgainer.com/enable-single-file-mhtml-support-chrome/?

title: Update the unsigned examples for the new format.
body: This uses the tool from #49.

title: Update the packaging tool to generate CBOR packages from a text format.
body:
This doesn't yet support signed manifests, and it's not tested as thoroughly as
I'd like, but it can generate packages for the first couple examples.

It assumes that #46 is accepted.

title: Consolidate resource-keys into the index.
body:
This requires the index where it used to be optional.

Fixes #41.

title: Remove COSE and use TLS1.3's signing algorithm.
body:
COSE is more complex than we need, and exposes us to any bugs in generic COSE
tools.

We're not necessarily going to allow certificates that can be used for TLS
traffic, but using their signing format removes one thing that'd block it.

These are requests from @agl.

title: Add a list of goals and non-goals.
body: It's a fairly long list. Did I miss anything?

title: Sketch an update to the package format and its signatures.
body: I haven't updated the Use Cases yet, but here are some thoughts on how we should update the format to deal with #33 (@bmeck), Ryan's security concerns in #31, #29 (@jianli-chromium), and #10, #11, and #12 (@lrosenthal). I've tried to mark all the places that still need work with "TODO", but I may have missed some.

title: Add some open questions, and refine a same-origin use case.
Add some discussion of the security issues.
Fix a bunch of typos and missing links.
body: I'm not sure I've got the right fix for each of these; feel free to say anything should be different.

title: Explicitly mandate X.509 cert and leave verification to host
body: fixes https://github.com/dimich-g/webpackage/issues/16

title: avoid colliding MIME for Content Index
body: fixes https://github.com/dimich-g/webpackage/issues/9 by using a sub tree of `application/package.index`

title: [WIP][DO-NOT-MERGE] extracting binaries
body: Will update as discussion on https://github.com/dimich-g/webpackage/issues/20 evolves.

title: [do not merge] MIME boundary => chunked encoding
body:
This allows for:

* streaming without worrying about collision and without the need to pre-parse the file
* signatures to be preserved even if chunk sizes differ due to streaming

fixes #6

title: No need for algorithm header, fixes #14
body: fixes #14

title: Explicitly note Content Index Entries content boundaries
body: Just explicit bound checking.

title: Adds an initial version of a packager script.
body:
This script can be updated alongside the explainer to give a concrete
answer to many format-related questions, and to uncover and resolve
ambiguities in the proposed spec.

Many parts of the spec are unimplemented as yet.

title: Adds a comment about relative indexing.
body: Fixes Issue #17.

title: readme: tiny typo fix
body: s/tot he/to the/

title: readme: tiny typo fix
body: s/subresourcves/resources/

title: Adds a few example pack files and component files.
body:
Also defines a ".attributes" file for those files that should be
included with either specific headers or from subpackages.
